subject: Monday Morning Quarterback
event:
The first Sunday of the NFL season has come and gone, and as usual, it was full of shocks, twists, and surprises.  I love pro football.

Brett looked pretty impressive in his first game as a Jet, though I think Mangini got too conservative in the second half.  The Dolphins were down, but the Jets missed several chances to put them out, so the game went down to the final seconds.  Chad Pennington played very well, and almost pulled the game out for the Fins.  It was quite a relief when Darrell Revis gathered in that final interception to end the threat.  The Dolphins look as though they are going to be a much better team this year.  Some nice play by the Jets rookie D-back Dwight Lowery.  Seems Tannenbaum made a good pick there.  On the other hand, our first round picks, Vernon Gholston and Dustin Keller, were both invisible.  I am hoping they will contribute more in future weeks.  The revamped o-line looked good, opening big holes for Thomas Jones, and our revamped d-line shut down Ricky Williams and the Dolphin running game.  Last year the Jets couldn't stop anybody's running game, so that was definitely a promising sign.

Next week is a much bigger test, of course.

Meanwhile, the Titans upset the Jaguars, the Bears shocked Peyton and the Colts, the Panthers silenced all of San Diego with a stunning last second victory over the Chargers... and Tom Brady went down, probably for the season, in New England's victory over the woeful Chefs.  The Patriots are not my favorite team, of course, and my loathing for Evil Little Bill is well known, but I still feel for the New England fans.  I know what it feels like.  As a Jets fan, I've been there.  Back in 1999, when Vinnie Testaverde went down in the opening game, clutching his Achilles and pounding on the ground... just thinking of it gives me a sick feeling in the pit of my stomach.  The whole season vanished in that instant, all the Jet superbowl dreams evaporating (though I still think we might have made the playoffs that year, if only Parcells had gone to Ray Lucas earlier, instead of sticking with Rick Mirer).

Whether the same fate awaits the Patriots remains to be seen, and will hinge largely on whether this kid Matt Cassell is the next Rick Mirer, or the next Jeff Hostetler.  We shall see.  In any case, you have my sympathies, Patriot fans.  Guess we'll need to wait till next year to see Brady against Favre.

comments.article:
I am not a Patriot's fan, but at the same time I have huge respect for Tom Brady. Not just because he is a Michigan man and that I irrationally root for Michigan each and every year, but because for the last set of years he has been the consummate professional. Tom Brady has been the cream of quarterbacks, most years not having the same weapons as Payton, yet still producing results.

In the spirit of good, exciting offensive football, *football* fans of all stripes should be disappointed that Tom Brady is injured, irregardless of what record the Patriots would have accrued.

At the same time, perhaps there is a reason that Matt Cassell has been kept around and he didn't play badly in his substitute role last week...he just also wasn't Tom Brady. Now the pressure begins.

It's a cliche, but to be the best, you have to beat the best. That's why I'm sad Brady went down. If this had happened just before the Superbowl last year, then the Giant's victory would have been far more hollow than the exultation it was.

It sucks to see someone get hurt doing their job, even if he is the quarterback of a team I frequently root against. Hopefully Brady will recover without too much suffering and play again someday.

That Jets game was fun to watch. I was thinking Favre would wilt in that 100 degree tropical heat but right after I thought that he threw a 50-something yard bomb for a TD.

It's going to be a good season all around the league I think. I pity the team who plays against the Colts next week. They're going to be up against an angry dog, so to speak.

Congrats on your Giants/Jets wins.

Jake Delhomme is a man of steel!

I'm not convinced that Titan/Jags was an upset. It's not like the Titans are bad - I wouldn't call any team out of the AFC South "bad". Titans have a stunning defense, and there were enough injuries to the Jag's defense that I was very unsurprised at this game.

The rest of the league though... wow. Wow.
Be strong. Resist the siren call. Donâ€™t blog. Write.
comments.subject: Oh, my dearest writer friend.

comments.article:
Quit putting the same stupid comment in HIS BLOG.

Don't want to read about football skip the entry and quit being an Ass to a marvelous writer. PERIOD.

Quit commenting, have some common sense.
comments.subject: Re: Oh, my dearest writer friend.

comments.upictitle: Mr. Cryptic Poster: Good Ol' Steve
comments.article: Thank you George for being more gracious than many Jets fans (and Giants fans... and Colts fans... and Steelers fans.. and...).  It was a terrible, terrible moment for Patriots fans.  It was jarring to see Favre QBing for the Jets, and even with Cassell, I think next week will be a lot of fun.

My sympathies go out to Tom Brady, though I have never liked him, and never will like him. Knee's not a good way to go. Though I am ashamed to admit I look forward to how this will spice up contention, not just in the AFC east, but it the AFC as a whole.

I thoroughly enjoyed the San Diego game, taking it all the way down to the wire, Indy looked horrible against the Bears, and how bout Atlanta smashing Detroit.

I have to admit that Favre looked good....in the first half. He really didn't show anything spectacular after that, and his 4th and 12 prayer shot for the endzone proved nothing to the contrary. The Jets looked better, but will have to mesh together to beat a Bills team that dominated a Seahawks team many considered an NFC favorite. However I do think that division is going to be a shootout this year as the Patriots will not be so dominating.

Congratulations to the Giants, excellent game on Thurs.

I look forward to reading your blog for next week's games, and as you say, any predictions are moot to the "shocks, twists, and surprises".
comments.subject: Week 1

comments.article:
The Dolphins look as though they are going to be a much better team this year.

It would be hard for them to be a worse team... *sigh*

My Bears looked amazing.  I'm excited to see them looking like a contender again.  They look even more like a contender with Brady down.  With Manning looking rusty last night and the Pats down an MVP, I wonder which team will emerge as the favorite this year.

Good for him. I'm glad he didn't go down in flames and make the whole leaving-Green-Bay debacle look even worse.

Now if only my corksmokin' Bucs would tighten it up. We need an offense like, bad.
comments.subject: Jet Favre and the New York Bretts...

comments.article:
All that is true ~ we'll see what happens right now, Mon night, as the Packers just started with the Vikes ~ Aaron Rodgers has a lot of people looking at him / cooking pressure on him. Hopefully he will fare better then Alex Smith did with my 49ers...He will.
Hopefully J.T Sullivan proves sucessful...
My football pool has us picking the winner of one game a week, can't use that team again, correct choiser moves on. I picked Pitts first week and moved on. Next week looks harder to choose, less clear runners.
comments.subject: Answer to George

comments.upictitle: The Greatest Fucking Genius of All Time: villain
comments.article: It's definitely looking like a good season for NY football fans, but this was one of the most painful football weekends for us fans in the Pacific Northwest.  The Seahawks lose to the Bills, the UW Huskies have a painful loss right in the end and the WS Cougars get murdered by 63 points.  Ouch.

It's just been a painful year for PNW sports. The Sonics are gone.  The Mariners should move to Manilla and become the Folders. With the exception of CWU, none of the college football teams are any good. The Seahawks...look like they may be in trouble without a huge step up from their nobody receivers.  Sad thing is, an 8-8 record might win the NFC West.

comments.upictitle: Jeanne / Xaviara al'Nady / Tita Kini: PolarBear
comments.article: Awwww geeeee, my Chiefs may be woeful, but the least you can do is spell the team name correctly! *sniff*

The Seahawks just plain stunk. Why is Seneca Wallace returning kicks? Or, better question: Why isn't Justin Forsett returning kicks? It's time to go out and see if Joe Horn or ANYONE with a game of WR experience in the NFL can come in and help out until Bobby Engram and Deion Branch get back. I wanted Holmgren gone after last season, and this first game is proving me right. More run, less pass Mike! Hasslebeck doesn't have anyone to throw to!!!!

Congrats to the Giants and Jets though.
comments.subject: Football

comments.article:
It would be amazing if Mr. Martin were to write a little one-off short story featuring Song of Ice and Fire characters playing a game of football.

"Rob with the snap, Jon drops back, looking - looking - Arya cuts out wide, pass is in the air! Hodor is confused and swats at the ball! That's your team, Hodor! Arya makes the catch, but she's pulled down just short of the first by Tyrion.
Boy, coach Eddard is really feeling that early season injury by Bran. Too bad telepathic mind control is illegal in this league!"

Nice run down of the opening week, George, but didn't you forget somebody? I'm sure it just slipped your mind to mention how that team in Dallas looked damn near unbeatable . . . My boys are bringing a whole load of payback this season, mark my words!

Nick.

comments.upictitle: Something Clever Here: Rome-Titus Improving by Ancarett
comments.article: At least the Ravens won.

As a Broncos fan, Monday Night's game had me almost dancing in the street. Yeah, it was the Raiders but still...Cutler looked awsome! It's going to be an interesting year in the AFC what with the Pats losing Brady, the Colts looking lost, the Dolts losing a heartbreaker. Maybe it's the Steelers conference to lose?

The longer as the Jets don't have to play rookies the better. I'm not convinced that the Dolphins will be a fair team. From what I've seen the best they can hope for is to be competitive against the B teams. And, guess what, they were.
The loss of a starting QB is crippling and teams suffering such a loss normally wails about it. Remember Keyshawn? NE didn't. Kudos to them. They seem full of confidence. Phil Simms commented that from what he saw he's surprised that Leinart started ahead of Cassel. Of course he also thought the Raiders competitive on Monday night.

I'm certain you have thought of maybe holding back on releasing these books until they're all finished...I'm curious what motivates you to release one at a time versus writing all of them, one good one after another, and releasing the finished tome in stages yearly or every other year or whatever. Or is that too intimidating to tackle at once? Or perhaps the urge to edit every already completed book and second guess and such would drive you batty?

Just curious.
Looking forward to the Dance!
comments.subject: A question

comments.article:
The number of players who are out for the season is just staggering

Burleson, Osi, Merriman, Brady etc

Yes, the Chefs usually beat their opponents like eggs in a bowl... their running backs can slice, dice, and chop their way through a defensive line... if the game goes into overtime, you're getting burned...

'Chefs' wouldn't be so bad, they could have a kitchen knife as their logo.

This year will mark the return of the Cowboys, they're going to reign over the NFL for a few years once again. That's my prediction and I'm sticking to it. But as for the Jets, yeah they won... but... yeah it's exciting when you toss one up for grabs and your team comes down with it, but... I dunno, I wouldn't get my hopes up if their games are going to rely on those kinds of plays. It is kinda cool though that a guy my age is still a pro quarterback.
comments.subject: woeful Chefs

comments.article: Why not let your readers comment on your political posts?
comments.subject: Question

comments.article:
I am a Patriots fan and am actually still quite optimistic about our chances. Based upon the supporting cast I believe Cassell can lead us to the playoffs.
But I would like to thank you for being a good fan unlike others who are celebrating his injury (did anyone see the New York Post on Monday? Despicable). I know you are probably happy he got injured due to the improved outlook it gives your team (as I would be if say Peyton were to be injured). But I would not wish injury upon any player (even Peyton), and it appears you would not either.
So once again, thank you for being a "good" sports fan, as there are many people out there who are not.
comments.subject: If only all fans were like you
